Updating your car's GPS system can be a bit of a process, but it's usually doable. The steps to update or reset your GPS system vary depending on the make and model of your car, as well as the type of GPS system you have. Here are some general steps you can follow:

1. **Check your owner's manual**: Look for a section on updating or resetting the GPS system. It might provide specific instructions or guidance on how to do it.
2. **Visit the manufacturer's website**: Go to your car's manufacturer website and search for "GPS update" or "software update" along with your car's model and year. You might find instructions or a downloadable update package.
3. **Check for software updates**: If your car has a touchscreen infotainment system, look for a "Settings" or "System" menu where you can check for software updates. Follow the on-screen instructions to download and install any available updates.
4. **Visit a dealership or authorized service center**: If you're not comfortable updating the software yourself, you can take your car to a dealership or authorized service center. They'll be able to update the software and ensure everything is working correctly.
5. **Reset the GPS system**: If updating the software doesn't work, you can try resetting the GPS system. This will vary depending on your car's make and model, but it usually involves pressing and holding a combination of buttons on the infotainment system or using a specific sequence of commands. Again, check your owner's manual or manufacturer's website for instructions.

Regarding your car's battery, it's a good idea to have it checked out by a mechanic to rule out any underlying issues. A fast-draining battery can be caused by a variety of factors, such as:

* A faulty alternator or battery sensor
* A parasitic drain (something is drawing power from the battery when the car is turned off)
* A weak or old battery
* A malfunctioning accessory or alarm system

Have the mechanic perform a battery test and inspect the electrical system to identify the cause of the issue.

Remember to also check your car's battery terminals and cables for any signs of corrosion or wear, as this can also affect the battery's performance.

I hope this helps! Let me know if you have any further questions.
